Award.AwardTitle: Estuarine Ecosystem Adaptation Due to Environmental Variability and Watershed Restoration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This doctoral dissertation will examine the combined influences of ecological restoration, sea-level rise, and environmental variability on changes in the food webs of coastal ecosystems. Estuaries produce highly productive recreational and commercial fisheries that feed billions and drive economies. Many large-scale ecosystem restoration efforts target changes in freshwater systems that impact the functioning, productivity, and biodiversity of downstream coastal waters. Simultaneously, environmental variability is driving changes in sea-level, temperature, and precipitation that are influencing the same characteristics of these same estuarine systems. The ecosystem model developed by this research will help resource managers and restoration practitioners design and plan for beneficial outcomes for coastal ecosystems given the complex interactions of these co-occurring drivers of change.<br/><br/>Modeling, prediction, and analysis of ecosystems impacted by the coupled effects of environmental variability and large-scale restoration efforts will lead to new knowledge of spatial and temporal estuarine ecosystem responses to these large-scale drivers. The project addresses the following questions: 1) How will changes in salinity range and variability, water depth, temperature, and bottom sediments affect the distribution of fishes, invertebrates, and seagrass coverage in estuaries? 2) How will future spatial and temporal ecosystem changes, resulting from the interactions of hydrological restoration and environmental change, affect productivity, fisheries landings, and food web structure in estuaries? The doctoral student will develop habitat suitability models to incorporate into the studentâ€™s previously calibrated and validated aspatial ecosystem model and predict future estuarine dynamics with the development of a spatially explicit and temporally dynamic food web model. The modeled ecosystem has broad spatial and temporal salinity variation, has an economically valuable sport fishery, nursery habitat for commercial fisheries, disturbed watershed and hydrologic regime, ecosystem-scale restoration effort, and is vulnerable to the ubiquitous threat of environmental variability and sea-level rise that reflects future changes in systems worldwide.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement grant for the project titled "Estuarine Ecosystem Adaptation Due to Environmental Variability and Watershed Restoration" was awarded to Dr. Scott H. Markwith (Principal Investigator) and Dr. Mason Smith (Co-Principal Investigator) in support of the completion of Dr. Smith's dissertation research in the Department of Geosciences at Florida Atlantic University (graduated with PhD in Geosciences, May 2022).

The goal of this project was to predict and analyze the responses of the Florida Bay tropical estuary to the impacts of climate change and large-scale restoration efforts in the Everglades ecosystem using a comprehensive ecosystem model.  The model involved the development of a food web and analysis of matter and energy movement through the food web over time, development of habitat suitability models under current conditions and under projected change in sea level, precipitation, temperatures, and restored freshwater inputs with climate change and completed Everglades restoration in 2060, and prediction of ecosystem health and fisheries outcomes for important recreational fisheries in the Florida Bay. The outcomes of this project will lead to a better understand of the dynamics of tropical estuary ecosystems in response to these large-scale climate and restoration drivers of environmental change.

We have predicted both positive and negative distribution shifts due to climate change and large-scale restoration for numerous species. We also found increases in the biomass of estuarine species, biomass distribution shifts that will benefit fisheries, and an overall increase in ecosystem resilience in the predicted future restored ecosystem. These predictions will provide an opportunity to ensure management strategies are designed appropriately to best achieve the desired results for the future of the Florida Bay ecosystem. In the study area, we have produced high-resolution environmental maps of current and future conditions in Florida Bay, which have provided equally high-resolution species distribution maps through habitat suitability analysis. Using these data, we have developed an ecosystem model which will be shared upon publication to the open source Ecopath community through Ecobase.org. In this way, the model will be capable of further developments by the PIs and the wider research community. 

The following products were produced due to this research funding:

One dissertation was completed leading to the fulfillment of the requirements of a PhD in Geosciences for Mason Smith:

Smith, M.J., 2022. Spatiotemporal Dynamics of the Florida Bay Ecosystem in Relation to Climate Change and Everglades Restoration (Doctoral dissertation, Florida Atlantic University).

Two conference presentations:

Smith, M., Chagaris, D., Paperno, R.., and Markwith, S. H.  Ecosystem Structure and Resilience of the Florida Bay Estuary: An Original Ecosystem Model with Implications for Everglades Restoration.  Presented at the 2021 Greater Everglades Ecosystem Restoration conference.

Smith, M., Chagaris, D., Paperno, R., and Markwith, S. H.  The Florida Bay ecosystem under a future climate and restoration plan.  152nd Annual American Fisheries Society Conference, Spokane, Washington, August 21-25, 2022. 

One manuscript was published in Marine and Freshwater Research:

Smith, M., Chagaris, D., Paperno, R., and Markwith, S. H.  2020.  Ecosystem Structure and Resilience of the Florida Bay Estuary: An Original Ecosystem Model with Implications for Everglades Restoration.  Marine and Freshwater Resarch vol. 72, p. 563-583.

Two manuscripts in review:

Smith, M., Chagaris, D., Paperno, R., Flaherty-Walia, K., and Markwith, S. H.  Species Distributions in a Changing Estuary: Predictions under Future Climate Change, Sea-Level Rise, and Watershed Restoration.  Estuaries and Coasts.

Smith, M., Chagaris, D., Paperno, R., and Markwith, S. H.  Tropical Estuarine Ecosystem Change Under the Interacting Influences of Future Climate and Ecosystem Restoration.  Global Change Biology.
